titleStmt.title: A confutation of the Anabaptists, and all others who affect not civill government; proving the lawfullnesse of it: and a full answer to all their cavills, that are, or can be made against it. With a nut-cracker for an unnaturall nut, whose shell is as hard as the scales of Leviathan, and the kernell of his heart as hard as a piece of the nether mill-stone, Iob 41.15.24. yet the hammer of Gods word that breaketh in pieces the rocks, Ier. 23.29. will break this nut, that all may see the devillish kernell that is in it. Also arguments against the Anabaptists, proving that infants borne of Christian parents ought to be baptized: with a full answer to all their cavills that are (or can be) made against it. Imprimatur Ja. Cranford.

The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
THE maine cau≈øe that moved me to undertake this Worke is this; many faithfull Chri≈øtians, and loyall Subjects are blamed to be enemies to Civill government, as al≈øo my ≈øelfe bearing a part of that reproach with them: now to cleare both my ≈øelfe and others in the≈øe divided and di≈øtracted times, J thought it not ami≈ø≈øe to di≈øcover them, and to make them knowne who they be that de≈øpi≈øe dominion, and ≈øpeake evill of dignities, Jude 8. that faithfull Chri≈øtians and loyall ≈øubjects may not be blamed, who are ≈øubject to Principalities and Powers, and willing to obey Magi≈øtrates, and ready to every good work, Titus 3.1, 2. Who every day that pa≈ø≈øeth over their heads put up prayers and ≈øupplications, interce≈ø≈øions and giving of thanks at the Throne of grace for Kings, and all in authority, that we may live a quiet and peaceable life, in all godline≈ø≈øe and hone≈øtie 1 Tim. 2.12. And as for mee, God forbid that I ≈øhould ≈øinne again≈øt the Lord in cea≈øing to pray for them, 1 Samuel 12.23. Tet Gods people were alwayes blamed to be enemies to civill authoritie. Ahab ≈øaid to Elijah, Art not thou he that troubleth I≈ørael? 1 Kings 18.17. And ≈øaith Haman that great Courtier, There is a certaine people ≈øcattered and di≈øperced among thy people in all the Provinces of thy Kingdome, and their Lawes are divers from all people, neither keep they the Kings Laws, E≈øther 3.8. Nay further, this Court-flatterer ≈øo prevailed with the King to get Letters ≈øealed with the Kings ≈øeale, to de≈øtroy, to kill, and cau≈øe to peri≈øh all Jewes, both young and old, little children and women in one day, even upon the thirteenth day of the twelfth Moneth (which is the Moneth Adar) and to take the
≈øpoyle of them for a prey, Ver≈øe 13. And it was told the King ≈øaying, Daniel, one of the captivity of the children of Judah, regardeth not thee, O King, nor the decree that thou ha≈øt ≈øigned, and ≈øo was ca≈øt into the Denne of Lions: but in the morning the King comes to the mouth of the Donne, and calls Daniel; to which hee an≈øwered, O King, live for ever, my God hath ≈øent his Angel, and hath ≈øhut the Lions mouths, that they have not hurt me, for as much as before him Innocencie was found in me; and again≈øt thee, O King, have I done no hurt, Daniel 6.13.20.21.22. And Paul was accu≈øed to be a pe≈øtilent fellow, and a mover of ≈øedition: but when the tryall came, neither again≈øt the Law of the Iewes, nor against the Temple, nor again≈øt Cae≈øar had he offended any thing at all, Acts 24. ‚Ä¢ .25.8. Nay further, they ≈øaid of Christ him≈øelfe to Pilate, If thou let this man goe, thou art not Cae≈øars friend, for he ≈øpeaketh again≈øt Cae≈øar: Iohn. 19.12. Yet Chri≈øt, although he was a true heire to the Crown and Kingdome of the Iewes, ≈øhewed him≈øelfe loyall to Civill Government, ≈øaying, Render to Cae≈øar the things that are Cae≈øars, and to God the things that are Gods, Matthew 22.21. And hee payed tribute to avoyd offence. Matthew 17.26, 27. although an heire to the Crowne, and free from Tribute; Thus in all ages, both all the faithfull, and Chri≈øt him≈øelfe was blamed to bee enemies to civill government: And now I come to our own age, witne≈ø≈øe tho≈øe three Worthies, and faithfull ≈øervants of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who pleading for God and the King, and declaring how tho≈øe Traiterous Prelates did intrench upon the Kings prerogative in many particulars; the≈øe men venturing lives and ≈øtates, and all outward comforts, through a tender affection they had to their Prince, as not being able to indure to ≈øee the wrong done to him, and be ≈øilent; and yet for ≈øpeaking, and declaring tho≈øe Traytors, they were puni≈øhed altogether, although they did expre≈ø≈øe ≈øuch Loyalty that I think their examples are not to be parallel'd; witne≈ø≈øe that renowned Doctor Ba≈øtwick, who laboured to maintaine the honour, and dignity, and prerogative Royall of our Soveraigne Lord the King; ≈øaying, Let the King live for ever: Had I a thou≈øand lives, I ≈øhould think them all too little to ≈øpen ‚Ä¢ for his Maje≈øties Royall Prerogative: and had I as much bloud in my veines as would ≈øwell the Thames, I would ≈øhed it every drop in this cau≈øe: And then wi≈øhing the people not to bee di≈øcouraged, nor daunted at the Prelates power, but bid them labour to pre≈øerve innocencie, and keep peace within, and goe on in the ≈øtrength of your God, and hee will never faile you in ≈øuch a day as this: Then ≈øaith he, as I ≈øaid before, ≈øo I ≈øay again, had I as many lives as I have haire ‚Ä¢
upon my head, or drops of bloud in my veines I would give them up all for this Cau≈øe. Yet all this could not free them from ≈øufferings, although Mordecai had ≈øaved the Kings life from the hands of Traytors, yet no honour is done to Mordecai: But the Lord hath all the≈øe things upon the File, and in his due time he will cau≈øe the King to read the the Chronicles, to finde out that which Mordecai hath done, and requite it, E≈øther 6.1. For behold thy ≈øervants are ready to doe what≈øoever my Lord the King ≈øhall appoint, 2 Samuel 15.15. Not as men-plea≈øers, but as the ≈øervants of Chri≈øt, doing the will of God from the heart, with good will doing ≈øervice, as to the Lord and not to men, Ephe≈øians 6.6.7. For we mu≈øt be ≈øubject, not onely for wrath, but for con≈øcience ≈øake, Romans 13.6. Yet not as bringing the con≈øcience under any humane power, but as in obedience to Gods command, who is the onely Lord of Con≈øcience, he ≈øaith, Let every ≈øoule be ≈øubject to the higher powers, Ver≈øe 1. Submit your ≈øelves to every Ordinance of man for the Lords ≈øake, whether it bee to the King, as ≈øupreame, and to Governours ≈øent by him, 1 Peter 2.14.15. And we honour and reverence them as the Deputies of God: for the powers that be are ordained of God, & their place is Gods Ordinance, Ver≈ø 2. He ≈øaith, By me Kings reigne, and Princes decree ju≈øtice; by me Princes rule, and Nobles, and all the Judges of the earth, Proverb; 8.15, 16. All Princes Iudges, and Magi≈øtrates beare the name of God, as being cloathed with his authority: GOD ≈øtandeth in the Congregation of the mightie, and judgeth among the Gods, I have ≈øaid yee are Gods; P≈øal. 82.16. Al≈øo we reverence them from Gods command, which ≈øaith, Feare God and honour the King, 1 Peter 2.17. Yea we must feare God and the King, not with a ≈ølavi≈øh, but with a filiall feare, My ≈øonne feare thou the Lord, and the King, Prov. 24.21. Thus we are highly to e≈øteem of civill government; for as the breath of our no≈øtrills is the Lords anoynted. Lam. 3.20. And when David would goe forth to war him≈øelfe, the people an≈øwered, Thou ≈øhalt not goe forth, for if we flie away, they w ll not care for us, neither if halfe of us dye, will they care for us; but now thou art worth ten thou≈øand of us, 2 Samuel 18.2.3. So then our lives and ≈øtates, and all wee have is not too deare to doe him ≈øervice. Now ≈øuch a one is a faithfull Chri≈øtian, and a loyall Subject: but becau≈øe ≈øome are like the unju≈øt Iudge, who neither feared God, nor regarded man, Luke 18.4. Yet they would bee thought to be faithfull Christians and loyall ≈øubjects: therefore to make them manife≈øt, I ≈øhall fir≈øt ≈øhew negatively who they are not, and then I will endeavour affirmatively to ≈øhew unto you who they are.

Fir≈øt, they are not that prophane blaspheming ‚Ä¢ rout that cling about his Maje≈øtie, who in their common talke dare Jehovah to his face to damne and ≈øinke them to the pit of Hell: but can the≈øe that are enemies to GOD and to them≈øelves bee either faithfull Chri≈øtians or loyall Subjects? it is impo≈ø≈øible. Such as the≈øe, ≈øaith the Prophet, being in any ≈øtraight, as when they are hungrie, they will cur≈øe their King and their God, and looke upward, I≈øaiah 8.21. And did not tho≈øe many of them at the fight at Newburie breath out their la≈øt breath, bla≈øpheming GOD and cur≈øing their King? but as they love cur≈øing ≈øo let it come unto them: as they cloath them≈øelves with cur≈øing like as with a garment, ≈øo let it it come into their bowells like water, and like oyl ‚Ä¢ into their bones, P≈øal. 109.17, 18. But although the≈øe men ≈øweare, yet faithfull Chri≈øtians and loyall ≈øubjects feare an Oath, Eccle≈øia≈øtes 9.2, They know that becau≈øe of ≈øwearing the Land mourneth, Jeremiah 23.10. They tremble at that flying rout that is ≈øent into the hou≈øe of the thiefe, and into the hou≈øe of the ≈øwearer to cut them off, Zechariah 5.3. Neither dare they cur≈øe the King, no not in their thought; for a Bird of the ayre ≈øhall carry the voyce, and that which hath wings ≈øhall tell the matter, Eccle≈øia≈øt. 10.20. It is written, that thou ≈øhalt not ≈øpeake evill of the Ruler of thy people, Acts 23.5. Then tho≈øe that cannot keep their tongues from ≈øwearing and their hands from ≈øtealing, declare plainely how they de≈øpi≈øe civill government, and tho≈øe Lawes that ≈øhould restraine tho≈øe cur≈øed practi≈øes, the≈øe licentious ≈øonnes of Belial, who ≈øeek to overthrow civill government by violence. But I ≈øhall bee more brief in the re≈øt, becau≈øe J am but in the Preface.

Secondly, the Romi≈øh Clergy or the Prelacy are enemies to civill government, who exempt them≈øelves from under their power, and not onely ≈øo, but they ≈øeek to take the power from the Magi≈øtrates to them≈øelves, and ≈øo to make them their va≈ø≈øalls: their cavills I have an≈øwered di≈øtinctly in this Booke.

Thirdly, the Antinomians and Famili≈øts are enemies to civill government, who ≈øeek to overthrow the eternall Law of God, on which the civill Law is built: now if the≈øe men take away the foundation whereon all our Lawes are built, what doe they el≈øe in this, but ≈øeeke to overthrow all civill government, that they may more freely ≈øatisfie their licentious affections?

Fourthly, the Browni≈øts, who call them≈øelves Independent; there bee many Sects of them, ≈øince Browne fir≈øt breached that Schi≈øme: ≈øome follow
Smith, ≈øome Iohn≈øon, ≈øome Robin≈øon, ≈øome Ain≈øworth, but they all da≈øh one again≈øt another, and all excommunicate them≈øelves from the Church of Chri≈øt: and, ≈øuith Pager, three or four hundred Browni≈øts have brought forth more Apo≈øtate Anabaptists and Arrians ≈øometimes in one yeare than ten thou≈øand members of the Reformed Dutch Church in Am≈øterdam hath done in ten years, though tempted by ≈øeducers as much as any others: of this he was an eyewitne≈ø≈øe, being then and there a member of the Cla≈ø≈øicall A≈ø≈øemblies; ≈øee his Epi≈øtle to the Arrow again≈øt the Browni≈øts. They deny that Magistrates ≈øhould have any hand in Religion, or the worke of Reformation: they affirme that Christian Princes and Magi≈øtrates have no more to doe in or about the Church than Heathen Princes: but here they intrench upon civill government, denying Cae≈øar his due: thus they would have civill government le≈ø≈øened, or limited. The Popi≈øh Clergy, they would have civill power removed from the Magi≈øtrate to them≈øelves: prophane people would have it connived at, in re≈øpect of them≈øelves; and Antinomians ≈øeek the violation of it by accident, in ≈øeeking to make voyd the Morall Law of God. Yet my purpo≈øe in writing this book was not to meddle with any of the≈øe; but as they ≈øet upon me in the pur≈øuit of tho≈øe grand enemies of civill government, which are that wicked generation of the Anabapti≈øts; the≈øe are they to whom I chiefely bend the whole drift of my di≈øputation, as being ab≈øolute enemies to the e≈ø≈øentiall being of civill government. It is neither conniving, nor limiting, nor removing that will ≈øerve their turnes, unle≈ø≈øe they have an utter extirpation of it: ≈øo then all the rest doe ≈øome way or other da≈øh again≈øt civill government: but the≈øe are profe≈ø≈øed enemies to it. Hence I conclude that none of the≈øe are the men whom I intend, when, J ≈øay, they are faithfull Chri≈øtians, and loyall ≈øubjects.

Now J an≈øwer affirmatively, that tho≈øe faithfull Chri≈øtians and loyall ≈øubjects are tho≈øe people that are faithfull to Luthers Prote≈øtation, and to Calvins Jn≈øtitution: the fir≈øt of the≈øe was the originall cau≈øe from whence the name of Prote≈øtants did fir≈øt ari≈øe: for when Luther did fir≈øt renounce that ≈øtrumpet of Rome, he cau≈øed them all that were with him to enter into a Prote≈øtation again≈øt all Popery, and popi≈øh Innovations; and all that took it were ever afters wards called Prote≈øtants: and we in this Kingdome have taken the very ≈øame Prote≈øtation again≈øt all Popery and popi≈øh Innovations; and I doubt not but we have many among≈øt us who will hazzard lives and ≈øtates and all they have, to maintaine that Protestation, and through Gods mercy will prove them≈øelves good Prote≈øtants. Now for Calvins In≈øtitution, I doe not call it ≈øo, as if he had made it of his owne head, but as a faithfull ≈øervant of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, he hath faithfully declared all the coun≈øell of God, as Paul did, Acts 20.27. that all may ≈øee what a Church Chri≈øt hath in≈øtituted in his word, and the
great ble≈ø≈øing of God upon this mans labours, and upon all that walked in the ≈øame ≈øteps.

Dear Chri≈øtian and loyal ≈øubject, thou that endevoure≈øt to have a con≈øcience voyd of offence both towards God and towards men, Acts 24.16. Thou that rendere≈øt to God his due, and to Cae≈øar his due; thou that obeye≈øt both the fir≈øt and ≈øecond table of the Law, thou that feare≈øt God, and ho ‚Ä¢ oure≈øt the King, and ≈øubmitte≈øt thy ≈øelf to every ordinance of man for the Lords ≈øake, I ≈øay to thee, Be faithful to the death, and thou ≈øhalt have the Crown of life, Rev. 2.10. Ye ≈øhall be hated of all men (≈øaith Christ) for my names ≈øake, but he that holdeth out to the end, the ≈øame ≈øhall be ≈øaved, Matth. 10.22. And for tho≈øe that do in any ca≈øe da≈øh again≈øt Gods Law, or mans Law, I would entreat them to read this Book with an impartiall eye, and it may be they may ≈øee their errour; and if ≈øo, then I would entreat them to imitate the faithfull Christian and loyall Subject; and ≈øo as they grow in ≈øtrength and wi≈øedome, they ≈øhall grow in favour with God and men, as our perfect patterne did, Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who ≈øaid, learne of me who am meek and lowly in heart, and you ≈øhall find re≈øt for your ≈øoules, Matth. 11.29. And ≈øo I commend thee to God, and the word of his grace, which is able to build thee up, and to give thee an inheritance among all them that are ≈øanctified, Acts 20.32. Now the God of pe ‚Ä¢ ce, that brought againe from the dead our Lord Ie≈øus that great Shepheard of the ≈øheep, through the bloud of the everla≈øting Covenant, make thee perfect in every good work, to doe his will, working in thee that which is well plea≈øing in his ≈øight, through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, to whom be glory for ever and ever. Amen Hebr. 13.20, 21.

div.head: A confutation of the Anabapti≈øts and all others who affect not Civill Government, proving the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of it, and a full an≈øwer to all their Cavils that are or can be made again≈øt it.
div.p: THere be two main arguments to prove the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of civill government among≈øt Chri≈øtians.

Fir≈øt, Civill government is very nece≈ø≈øary, and that appears in many perticulars, ≈øuch as the≈øe; It is nece≈ø≈øary to defend the outward wor≈øhipping of God, and to defend the ≈øound Doctrine of Godline≈ø≈øe, and the ≈øtate of the Church; and to frame our life to the fellow≈øhip of men, and to fa≈øhion our manners to civill righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and to procure us into Friend≈øhip one with another, and to nouri≈øh common peace and quietne≈ø≈øe. div.p: And the people bind them≈øelves to the King in the Oath of Allegiance.

BUt now ≈øtep out the Anabapti≈øts, who de≈øpi≈øe government, ≈øaying, all ≈øwearing is unlawfull; for ≈øay they, Chri≈øt ≈øaith, ≈øwear not at all, Mat. 5.34. Again, the Apo≈øtle is ≈øo far from denying the lawful u≈øe of ≈øwearing, that hee gives a ≈øufficient rea≈øon to prove the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of it in ≈øome ca≈øes for ≈øaith he men verily ≈øweare by the greater, and an oath for confirmation is the end of all ≈øtrife, Heb. 6.16. Now to know what an oath is, we ≈øhall ≈øee by the parts of it, which are two, Confe≈ø≈øion and Imprecation: Confe≈ø≈øion is threefold, though for the outward forme the words be few: Fir≈øt, a man confe≈ø≈øeth that which he ≈øweareth to be true

I an≈øwer, a man may lawfully ≈øweare, when the Magi≈øtrate mini≈øtreth an oath unto a man upon a ju≈øt occa≈øion, for the Magi≈øtrate hath the power of God in this ca≈øe, and therefore when he ju≈øtly requires it of a man, then he may lawfully ≈øwear.

I an≈øwer, when ye ≈øee the≈øe things come to pa≈ø≈øe, know ye that the kingdome of God is nigh at hand, Lu 21.24.25.27.31. Now will you know when wars ≈øhall cea≈øe? I an≈øwer, when the Son of Man ≈øhall come with power, and great glory, then is that Kingdome of God at hand, in which there ≈øhalbe no wars, but then all that offend ≈øhalbe gathered out of his Kingdome, and ca≈øt into the furnace of fire, and the righteous ≈øhall ≈øhine as the ≈øun in the Kingdome of their Father, Math. 13.41, 42, 43. Then wars ≈øhall cea≈øe when there ≈øhalbe none in that Kingdome that offends, but the≈øe offenders mu≈øt be in the Church, till the very judgement day at the end of the world: The Angels which are the Reapers, ≈øhall take out tho≈øe tares that did offend, and ca≈øt them into hell fire; then ≈øhall the ≈øecond Adam re≈øtore to the Saints all the creatures in their fir≈øt perfection, after that they are purified by fire, at that day the Saints ≈øhall inherit all things, and not before: For the fir≈øt Adam by ≈øin brought vanity and corruption upon all the creatures, but at that day the creatures ≈øhalbe purified and purged from their vanity and corruption, and then re≈øtored to the Saints alone, & ≈øo they ≈øhall remain for ever; for the Second Adam wil re≈øtore againe to the Saints all that they lo≈øt, and not as they are now corrupted & cloathed with vanity: For the new heavens and the new earth which I will make, ≈øhall remain before me, ≈øaith the Lord, I≈øa 66.22. Of that Kingdome there ≈øhalbe no end, Luke 1.33. Now becau≈øe the Church ≈øhalbe pe≈øtered with many enemies till the day of judgement, the ≈øword of the Magi≈øtrate is nece≈ø≈øary to keep down the ≈øeditious ≈øtirs of unquiet men, which trouble all Kingdomes with violent oppre≈ø≈øions and hainous evill doings, then Magi≈øtrates ought to defend them that are troubled, and to pre≈øerve the lawes & di≈øcipline with purity, which is the only means to regulate ≈øuch wicked men to better obedience; ≈øhall Theeves that rob a few be puni≈øhed, and ≈øhall they ≈øuffer whole Countreys to be ≈øpoiled with robberies; ≈øo then the chiefe Magi≈øtrate is not only to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe private injuries with judiciall puni≈øhments, but al≈øo mu≈øt defend with war the Dominions committed to his charge again≈øt any forraign inva≈øion what≈øoever, and ≈øuch wars by the te≈øtimony of Scripture in many places are lawfull.

Thirteenthly, they object that in the new Te≈øtament is neither witne≈ø≈øe nor example which teacheth that war is a thing lawfull for Chri≈øtians: I an≈øwer, the ≈øame rule that was to the Jewes remaines ≈øtill for Chri≈øtians, and there can be no cau≈øe to the contrary why Magi≈øtrates ≈øhould not now defend Chri≈øtians a≈øwel as they did the Jewes. Secondly, we ≈øhould not look for a full declaration of the≈øe things in the writings of the Apo≈øtles, for their purpo≈øe was not to frame a Civill State, but to e≈øtabli≈øh and to ≈øettle the ≈øpirituall Kingdome of Chri≈øt. Thirdly, if
Chri≈øt had intended that wars ≈øhould end at his comming, he would have ≈øaid to tho≈øe Souldiers which demanded of him ≈øaying, what ≈øhall we doe? Luke 3.14. I ≈øay his an≈øwer would have been this, ca≈øt away your weapons, and utterly withdraw your ≈øelves from war, but he ≈øhewes no di≈ølike of their being Souldiers, only he coun≈øels theat to be content with thear wages, and to doe violence to no man; yet by the way, I approve not of every light-occa≈øion to be ground ≈øufficient to goe to wars, unle≈ø≈øe they be driven to it by extreathe nece≈ø≈øity: For as Cicero, a heathen man ≈øaid, our going to war ≈øhould tend to peace, for war ≈øhould be ≈øought onely, when no other meanes will procure peace: La≈øtly they ought not to goe to warre upon any private affection, but as they are ≈øen≈øible of ≈øome injury doÃÑe to their Kingdome, which they are charged to keepe in peace, for if any private affection ≈øhould move them for wars, they abu≈øe the power committed to them; which was not given them for their owne Commodity, but for their Kingdomes benefit; thus they may u≈øe Garri≈øons and Fortifications to defend the borders of their Countries, and if any trouble ari≈øe, they may joyne their Forces together to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the common Enemy which would ≈øpoile their Kingdome, which they are charged to keepe in peace and ≈øafety.

The Apo≈øtle compares the fight of faith, that ≈øpirituall combate the child of God „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ corruptions, to the bodily fight with open enemies to the Church of Chri≈øts which ≈øhewes the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of wars undertaken by Chri≈øtians for defence of their Religion, now the good ≈øouldier mu≈øt give him≈øelfe wholly to it, and ≈øtrive lawfully, and he ≈øhall be crowned 2 Tim. 3 4 5. And we read of rare Chri≈øtians that were Souldiers, the Centurion had ≈øouldiers under him, and yet he had ≈øuch a ≈øaith, the like was not found in I≈ørael, Mat. 8.9.10. And Cornelius was a devout man, and a Captain of the Italian Band, and he had devout ≈øouldiers under him, Acts 10.1.2.7. And Paul was guarded by a Band of ≈øouldiers, Acts 23.23.24. We read that Gog and Magog will compa≈ø≈øe the Campe of the Saints, Revel. 20.8.9. But what, ≈øhall not this Camp of Saints re≈øi≈øt them? I ≈øaw the Bea≈øt and the Kings of the Earth, and their Armies gathered together to make war again≈øt him that ≈øate on the hor≈øe, (marke) and again≈øt his Army, and the Bea≈øt was taken, Revel. 19.19.20. But what, was this done without any fight? did this Army of Chri≈øtians, and this Camp of Saints ≈øtand all for cyphers? You ≈øhall ≈øee Ieru≈øalem compa≈ø≈øed about with Armies, Luke 22.20. And there ≈øhall be warres, for all the≈øe things mu≈øt come to pa≈ø≈øe, Mar. 24.6. It is ≈øpoken indefinitely, that if one King goe to war with another, they ought to with≈øtand him if they be able, Luke 14.31. As we would doe again≈øt a thiefe, and not ≈øuffer our hou≈øe to be broken up, Mat. 24.43. (≈øaith Chri≈øt) I came to ≈øend fire on the earth, & it is already kindled, Luke 12.49. I came not to ≈øend peace, but a ≈øword, Mat. 10.34. Then he that hath no ≈øword, let him ≈øell his garment and buy one, Luke 22.36. And re≈øi≈øt unto bloud, Heb. 12.4. Then tho≈øe that thinke their lives too deare for Chri≈øt and his Go≈øpell, are unworthy of either, Mark 8.35. & ill members both to Church and State.

Hence we may gather, that if this be ≈øo, then Tributes and Taxes are lawfull Revenues for Princes, which they may chiefly imploy to ≈øu≈øtaine their common charges of their Office, and likewi≈øe u≈øe to their private Royalty and honour of their Princely ≈øtate and dignity, as wee may ≈øee by the examples of many holy Kings in Scripture, which according to the State of their per≈øons which they did beare, were ≈øumptuou≈øly maintained of the common charge, and we read in Ezek. 48.21. That there was a very large portion of land a≈ø≈øigned to the King, &c. Yet again Princes ≈øhould remember, that their trea≈øure chambers are not ≈øo much their owne private coffers, as the Trea≈øuries of the whole People; therfore ≈øaith Paul, For this cau≈øe pay we tribute, for they are Gods Mini≈øters, attending continually upon this very thing, to execute wrath upon him that doth evill, and he is the Mini≈øter of God to thee for good, render therefore tribute to whom tribute is due, Rom. 13. So then they may not prodigally wa≈øte and ≈øpoile what they are betru≈øted with, for if they doe, it is manife≈øt wrong to the people; nay it is no le≈ø≈øe then mo≈øt cruelly and unnaturally ≈øpilling the bloud of the people, for their Impo≈øitions and Sub≈øidies, and other kind of tributes are but the ≈øupports of publique nece≈ø≈øity: Then to weary the poore Communalty without cau≈øe, is tyrannicall extortion, the≈øe things con≈øidered, doe not encourage Princes to wa≈øtefull expence and ryot, but rather it behoveth them with pure con≈øcience before God to doe all that they are bound to dee, le≈øt by their wicked boldne≈ø≈øe they be de≈øpi≈øed of God; and they mu≈øt be raught by them to whom it belongs, how much is lawfull for them, neither is this Doctrine needle≈ø≈øe for private men, they mu≈øt not ra≈øhly and ≈øtubbornly give them≈øelves leave to grudge at the expences of Princes, although they exceed common and civill mea≈øure, ≈øee Calvin In≈øti. 4.20.13.

Here it may be demanded by what rule Civill Government is to be regulated: I an≈øwer, by the Civill and po≈øitive Lawes of that Kingdome from which they receive their authority and dignity of civill Magi≈øtrates, the≈øe Lawes are as ≈øtrong ≈øinewes of Common-weales, or as Cicero calleth them, the ≈øoules, without which the Magi≈øtrate cannot ≈øtand, neither have they without the Magi≈øtrate any force, for the Law may be called a dumb Judge, and the Magi≈øtrate a living Law.

Now the Jewes had three ≈øorts of Lawes, the Ceremoniall, which was to them a darke Go≈øpell, ≈øhewing forth Chri≈øt to them in darke Types and ≈øhadows, but ble≈ø≈øed be God, the vaile is taken away to us, and Chri≈øt is more clearly ≈øet forth to us ≈øince the publication of the Go≈øpell, and Chri≈øt is come, the ≈øub≈øtance of all tho≈øe dark Types and ≈øhadowes. Secondly, they had the Judiciall Law, which was the civill or po≈øitive Law of their Common-wealth; ≈øo an≈øwerable to this, wee have our po≈øitive Lawes of this Kingdome. Thirdly, they had the eternall Morall Law of God, which commandeth ≈øimply without guile to wor≈øhip God with pure faith and godly life. Secondly, it commandeth to imbrace man with unfained love, it is the true and eternall rule of all righteous walking both to God and men, and it is pre≈øcribed to men of all ages and times who are willing to frame their lives to the will of God, for this is his eternall and unchangeable will, that he him≈øelfe ≈øhould
be wor≈øhipped of us all, and that we ≈øhould mutually love one another; So then although the judiciall or po≈øitive Lawes of the Jewes be taken away, yet the perpetuall duties of the Morall Law abide for ever.

Hence I gather, that every Nation hath that liberty left them to make ≈øuch Lawes as they ≈øhall fore≈øee to be mo≈øt profitable for them, but they mu≈øt be framed after the perpetuall rule of charity, they mu≈øt be grounded upon the ≈øame foundation, although they may differ in the form-from other Nations: Now the Law of God which we call morall, is nothing el≈øe but a te≈øtimony of the naturall Law that was written in the heart of man by creation, & ≈øome reliques of it are ≈øtill remaining in man, this morall law mu≈øt be the marke, and end, and rule of all Lawes; then what≈øoever lawes ≈øhall be framed according to that rule, and directed to that mark, and limited to that end, there is no cau≈øe why we ≈øhould di≈øallow them, although they differ from the Jewi≈øh Law, or one Kingdome from another in the admini≈øtration of it: as for example; the law of God forbiddeth ≈øtealing, now the petialty of theft is ≈øet downe in the civill lawes of the Jewes, to re≈øtore five oxen for an oxe and foure ≈øheep for a ≈øheep, Exod. 22.1. Now other Nations puni≈øhed theft with recompence of double, the lawes that followed afterwards made difference between manife≈øt theft and that which was not manife≈øt, and ≈øome proceeded to bani≈øhment, ≈øome to whipping and ≈øome at la≈øt to the puni≈øhment of death: Again, for fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øing among the Jewes was puni≈øhed with recompence of equall paine Deut, 19.18. In ≈øome places onely with great ≈øhame, in ≈øome places with hanging, in other≈øome with the cro≈ø≈øe; and for man-≈ølaughter, all lawes univer≈øally do revenge with bloud, yet with divers kinds of death: & for adultery, in ≈øome places were ordained great puni≈øhment, and in ≈øome le≈ø≈øer, yet we ≈øee for all this diver≈øity, all tend to the ≈øame end, for they all agree togehter to puni≈øh tho≈øe offences which the eternall law of God conde ones, as man-≈ølaughter, thefts, adulteries, fal≈øe w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e≈ø≈øing, &c. But in the manner of puni≈øhment they agree not, neither is it needfull that they ≈øhould, for in ≈øome Countries they mu≈øt ≈øhew vigour with horrible examples again≈øt man ≈ølayers or el≈øe they will be immediately ruined with murders and robberies, and ≈øometimes puni≈øhments ought to be more ≈øevere then at other times, as in the time of was, all humanity would be ca≈øt away unle≈ø≈øe they then u≈øe unwonted fear of puni≈øhments; and ≈øome Countreys are more addicted to ≈øome certaine vice, which mu≈øt be the more ≈øharply puni≈øhed to ≈øtop the ≈øpreading of it. Hence we mu≈øt not conceive that the eternall law of God is abrogated, and new Lawes made and put in the place thereof, and prefe red above it, for they are not preferd above it ≈øimply, but in re≈øpect of the times, places and Nations, neither was the Morall Law given by Mo≈øes, but to Adam before he ≈øinned, and manife≈øted in writing to Mo≈øes, not for the Jewes only, but for all Nations, and to be the ground of all their po≈øitive Lawes.

div.head: Objections again≈øt our po≈øitive Law.
div.p:
FIr≈øt, being the 14th. in number, they object again≈øt our lawes and Magi≈øtrates, ≈øaying, that they are of no u≈øe for Chri≈øtians, for we cannot lawfully crave
their aid in any ≈øuite at law, becau≈øe they are forbidden to revenge, or to have any controver≈øie. I an≈øwer, Paul ≈øaith that he is the Mini≈øter of God for good, and he is ≈øo ordained of God, and for that very purpo≈øe, attending continually upon this very thing, Rom. 13.16. To defend us from the malice & injuries of mi≈øchievous men, therefore we ought to pray for tho≈øe in authority, that we may live a quiet & a peaceable life, but unle≈ø≈øe it be lawfull to u≈øe ≈øuch helpe and benefit, they were given to us in vaine from the Lord, and ≈øaith Demetrius, if any man have a matter again≈øt another, the law is open, and there are Deputies, let them implead one another; and if you enquire any thing concerning other matters, it ≈øhalbe determined in a lawfull a≈ø≈øembly, Acts 19, 28, 39. And ≈øaith Chri≈øt: Agree with thine adver≈øary quickly while thou art in the way with him, le≈øt thine adver≈øary deliver thee to the Iudge, and the Iudge deliver thee to the Sergeant, and thou be ca≈øt into pri≈øon; verily I ≈øay unto thee, thou ≈øhalt not come out till thou ha≈øt paid the uttermo≈øt farthing, Math. 5.25, 26. Upon the≈øe words ≈øaith Mr. Perkins, Chri≈øt here alloweth of the Magi≈øtrate and ≈øear of judgement, 1. Of his proceeding again≈øt the guilty, in delivering him to the officer, 2. Of the office of the Sergeant, 3. Of ca≈øting guilty per≈øons into pri≈øon, 4. Of ≈øuing at the Law, when right cannot be had by other lawfull meanes, but law mu≈øt not be the fir≈øt cour≈øe that we take in ≈øeeking our right, we mu≈øt rather ≈øuffer ≈øome wrong, and ≈øeek ‚Ä¢ to end the matter by friends, and u≈øe law, as Phi≈øitians u≈øe poy≈øons, when gentle phy≈øick will not ≈øerve the turne, then in ca≈øe of extreamity, they do mini≈øter ≈øtronger phy≈øick, yea ≈øome poy≈øon it ≈øelfe, ≈øo when we cannot otherwi≈øe precure our peace and right, then we may lawfully take the benefit of the law.

15. But they object, tho≈øe which ≈øeek helpe at the Magi≈øtrates hands for them≈øelves and others, do prevent that help which they ≈øhould have from God their heavenly defender, I an≈øwer, not ≈øo, for the Magi≈øtrate is the mini≈øter of God ordained for this very end, to deliver his afflicted people from the cruell hands of wicked and malicious men; but they will reply in tho≈øe words of Chri≈øt, ≈øaying, re≈øi≈øt not evill, but who≈øoever ≈øhall ≈ømite thee on the right cheek, turne to him the other al≈øo, and if any man ≈øue thee at the law, and take away thy coat, let him have thy cloak al≈øo. I an≈øwer, here Chri≈øt would have them ≈øuffer double injury, rather then go to law, e≈øpecially when they ≈øeeke to revenge them≈øelves by law; all this I grant, and more al≈øo, for their whole life ≈øhould be a continuall bearing the cro≈ø≈øe, when one is gone to fit them≈øelves for another; They mu≈øt doe good to them that doe them wrong, and wi≈øh well to tho≈øe that cur≈øe them, and, which is the only victory, overcome evill with good, being thus minded, they wil not ≈øeeke eye for eye, and tooth for tooth, as the Phari≈øees taught their Di≈øciples to de≈øire revenge; yet all this hinders not, but that a Chri≈øtian may u≈øe the lawfull help of the Magi≈øtrate to pre≈øerve their goods, or through their love and zeale to the Common-wealth, they may ≈øue a malefactor at the Bar for his life.

16. They will object that contendings in law are altogether forbidden & condemned by Paul, where he ≈øaith: Brother goeth to law with brother, and that before
unbeleevers; Now therefore there is utterly a fault among you, becau≈øe ye goe to law one with another: Why do you not rather ≈øuffer wrong, why do you not rather ≈øuffer your ≈øelves to be defrauded? 1 Cor. 6.6, 7. I an≈øwer, Paul him≈øelf went to law with his adver≈øaries, for ≈øaid Paul, I ≈øtand at Ce≈øars judgment ≈øcate, where Tought to be judged, Acts 25.10. And he an≈øwered for him≈øelfe, ≈øaying; Neither again≈øt the law of the Iewes, nor again≈øt the Temple, nor again≈øt Ce≈øar have I offended any thing at all; for if I be an offender, or have committed any thing worthy of death, I refu≈øe not to dye, ver≈ø. 8.11. Then how can any wi≈øe man think that Paul went to condemn that which he him≈øelfe did? if this were true, we might retort tho≈øe words back upon him≈øelfe, ≈øaying; Thou that judge≈øt another, condemn ≈øt thy ≈øelfe, for thou that judge≈øt, do≈øt the ≈øame things, Rom. 2.1. And as the Jewes ≈øaid to Chri≈øt, Phy≈øitian, heale thy ≈øelfe, ≈ølandering his holy and blamele≈ø≈øe life that never did ami≈ø≈øe, neither was guile found in his mouth; and ≈øo Paul living in all good con≈øcience both towards God and towards man, Acts 24.16. Yet the≈øe men would here fa≈øten a reproach upon him, to teach contrary to his practice; wel theÃÑ the true meaning of Paul was this, that becau≈øe the CorinthiaÃÑs were very much given to contentions and ≈øtrivings at law, and that before heathen Judges, which became a great ≈øcandall to their profe≈ø≈øion, in not ≈øhewing Chri≈øtian meekene≈ø≈øe one to another which they ought to do, yea they were ≈øo far from covering wrongs, that they greedily coveted one anothers goods, and ≈øo provoked one another to wrath: ≈øo that here Paul blames their abu≈øe of this ordinance, when every trifling matter was enough to make them run to the Court of Law, and the lea≈øt occa≈øion that could be, was enough to kindle ≈øtrife and contention, and to reveoge them≈øelves one of another; This Paul blames, but not the lawfull u≈øe of this ordinance appointed of God to pre≈øerve peace and unity, ≈øo that you ≈øee in all this that civill government is both lawfull and very nece≈ø≈øary; then this may di≈øcover the wickedne≈ø≈øe of that man of ≈øin the Antichri≈øt, who ≈øits in the Temple of God, and exalts him≈øelfe above all that is called God, and ≈øhewing him≈øelfe that he is God, 2 The≈ø. 2.4. Thus again≈øt God him≈øelfe, and again≈øt his Deputies who beare his name, he hath for many hundred yeares u≈øurped a ≈øupremacy over civill government, being the highe≈øt rebellion that ever was in the world; for ≈øaith the Apo≈øtle: Every ≈øoule mu≈øt be ≈øubject to the higher powers, Rom. 13.1. But let us heare what he hath to ≈øay for him≈øelfe.

Fir≈øt, he objecteth again≈øt this place, ≈øaying, that it is to be under≈øtood of tho≈øe that to be ≈øubject, but the Popes them≈øelves are exempted; To this I an≈øwer, if the Pope have a ≈øoule, he mu≈øt be ≈øubject to civill government; this is not to bring the ≈øoule it ≈øelfe into ≈øubjection to civill government, but this is ≈øpoken of all men living, who have ≈øouls, tho≈øe men, their words and actions, body and goods, are to be ≈øubject to civill government; but in this reply of his exempting him≈øelfe from all ≈øubjection to civill power, he plainly ≈øhews him≈øelfe to be that Antichri≈øt who exalts him≈øelfe above all that is called God, meaning all civill powers and Magi≈øtrates who are Gods Deputies, and who alone beare him name, P≈øalme 82.1.2. When they
are upon the Throne of judgement, God judgeth among the Gods.

Secondly, but they object that Vzziah the King burnt Incen≈øe upon the altar of Incen≈øe: Then Azariah the Prie≈øt went in after him, and four≈øcore Prie≈øts of the Lord that were valiant men, and they with≈øtood Uzziah the King, and Azariah the chiefe Prie≈øt, and all the Prie≈øts looked upon him, and behold he was leprous in his forehead and they thru≈øt him out from thence, 2 Chron. 26.17, 18.20. Here ≈øay they, the Prie≈øt depo≈øed the King, and thru≈øt him out of the Temple: I an≈øwer, Azariah re≈øi≈øted the King not by force or violence, but by word only and admonition, whereby they cau≈øed him to depart out of the Temple; for it is ≈øaid, that hee him≈øelfe ha≈øted to go out, ver≈ø. 20. Neither was he depo≈øed from his government, but being by God ≈øtricken ≈øodainly with a lepro≈øie, he was by the law ≈øhut out from the company and ≈øociety of men, and ≈øo di≈øabled to govern, although the right of it ≈øtill belonged unto him.

Thirdly, they object that example of Iehojada the high Prie≈øt who depo≈øed Qu: Athaliah from her Kingdome, and ≈øet up young Ioa≈øh to be King, 2 Chron. 23. Hence they conclude that the Pope hath authority to depo≈øe Kings and Emperours: I an≈øwer, Iehojadah the high Prie≈øt was next to the King in blood, 2 Chron. 22.11. And was one of the States of the Land, who depo≈øed her not alone by him≈øelfe, but by the common con≈øent of all the States and Peeres of the Land, ≈øee Chap. 23.1, 2. He indeed is chiefly named, becau≈øe he was the chiefe of them in blood; neither did he ≈øet up Ioa≈øh, but helped to maintain his right which was u≈øurped by Athaliah: in a word, he protected the right heire, but could not him≈øelfe depo≈øe nor make over the Kingdome unto him; hence I conclude, that to exempt the Clergie from under the authority of the Civill Magi≈øtrate is rebellion.

Fourthly, they object that Kings and Princes of their bounty have granted the≈øe priviledges unto them. I an≈øwer, the law of nature acknowledgeth a civill ≈øubjection, and the law of God ≈øtraightly commands it, ≈øaying: Let every ≈øoule be ≈øubject to the higher powers, Rom. 13. And put them in mind to be ≈øubject to principalities and powers, to obey Magi≈øtrates, and to be ready to every good worke, Titus 2.1. Then I conclude hence, that no law of any man may offer violence, or derogate from either of the≈øe.

Thirdly, they alledge that the power of the keyes is given to the Church: I an≈øwer, that it is ≈øo, yet the u≈øe and admini≈øtration thereof belongs to the Mini≈øters onely in their di≈øpen≈øation of the word; So then none are to meddle in the Mini≈øtery but they that have a lawfull calling thereunto: Now it belongs to God alone to call men to the mini≈øtery, Paul an Apo≈øtle, not of men, nor by men, but by Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, Gal 1.1. But it may be they will object the≈øe words of Paul; For ye may all prophe≈øie one by one, that all may learn, and all may be comforted, 1 Cor. 14.31. I an≈øwer, this is Schooles di≈øputation. Next, he blames both the Magi≈øtrates and Divines that are a≈ø≈øembled, for two things. Fir≈øt, for going about to reduce all our di≈øtractions and Schi≈ømes into one way of wor≈øhipping God I an≈øwer, there is but one way to heaven, ≈øaith the Lord, I will gvie them one heart and one way, that they may feare me for ever, Jer. 32.39. But will not they have our di≈øtractions and ≈øchi≈ømes reduced to one way of wor≈øhipping God, then ≈øaith Paul, marke them which cau≈øe divi≈øions and offences contrary to the doctrine that ye have learned, and avoid them; for they that are ≈øuch feare not the Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, Rom. 16.18. The ≈øecond thing for which he blames the collective body of our Kingdome, for ≈øuppo≈øing that the land is ≈øcourged for this cau≈øe, that ≈øo many Religions are ≈øuffered, affirming the contrary, that the cau≈øe of judgments, wrath and ≈øtripes is this, that all Religions are not ≈øuffered: his rea≈øon is, fir≈øt ≈øaith he, the con≈øciences of con≈øcious men are as deare to them as their lives, 2. Hatred will pur≈øue them that again≈øt Gods rule will judge men for their con≈øciences; this la≈øt rea≈øon is grounded upon a fal≈øe foundation, for they do not take upon them to judge the con≈øcience; we grant with him, that God alone is the judge of con≈øcience: and I have ≈øhewed at large, that Magi≈øtrates do but command the outward man, as his words and actions; and if they offend herein, they may puni≈øh them in their bodies and goods, ≈øo then they may command outward conformity in the wor≈øhip of God, and if they be Hypocrites, it is from them≈øelves who are not obedient to Gods command, which alone reacheth the heart: It is true, we mu≈øt obey them for con≈øcience ≈øake, yet not from their command, but from Gods command, Titus 3.1. Now for his rea≈øon that is built upon this, he ≈øaith, what hatred mu≈øt needs pur≈øue them that bring all religions into one, although it may be proved the true Religion; but ≈øaith Chri≈øt: If the world hate you, ye know that it hated me before it hated you: If ye were of the world the world would love his owne: but becau≈øe I have taken you out of the world, therefore the world hateth you, John 15.18, 19. Ble≈ø≈øed are ye when men revile you, and ≈øay al manner of evil again≈øt you fal≈øely for my names ≈øake, Math. 5.11. But ≈øaith he, our con≈øciences are as deare to us as our lives. And that Strumpet in the Prov. 30.20. can wipe her mouth, and ≈øay ≈øhe hath done no wickedne≈ø≈øe; and we ≈øeldome heare a Malefactor plead guilty; then is con≈øcience ≈øuch a perfect rule, or mu≈øt it rule the Word of God, or Gods word rule the con≈øcience? Neither doe they take upon them to frame a government for the Church, but they ≈øearch the word, and endeavour to find out that forme that God him≈øelfe hath ≈øet down in his word; and I doubt not, but ere long, if they humbly ≈øubmit them≈øelves to the Lord, and be a≈øhamed of their owne wayes, that they have a long time walked in, that the Lord will ≈øhew them the forme of the hou≈øe, and the fa≈øhion thereof, and the goings out thereof, and all the formes thereof, and all the ordinances thereof, and all the lawes thereof, and write it in their ≈øight, that they may keepe the whole forme thereof, and all the ordinances thereof, and do them, Ezek 43.11. To the great prai≈øe of his name, and to the comfort of all his people.

div.head: Arguments again≈øt the Anabapti≈øts, proving that Infants borne of Chri≈øtian Parents ought to be baptized; with a full an≈øwer to all their Cavills that are, or can be made again≈øt it.

Secondly, the Apo≈øtles practi≈øe ≈øheweth, that they under≈øtood that infants were included in that command of Chri≈øt; for when they came to any family, if but the parents beleeved, and were baptized, they baptized all the hou≈øhold.
